unnormalised: A small robotics team from IIT Delhi has announced a breakthrough in agricultural automation. The project, codenamed 'KrishiBot', aims to alleviate labor shortages and improve crop yields across Indian farms. Initial trials in Haryana have shown promising results, with the robot demonstrating autonomous weeding capabilities.
normalised: A small robotics team from I-I-T Delhi has announced a breakthrough in agricultural automation. The project, codenamed 'KrishiBot', aims to alleviate labor shortages and improve crop yields across Indian farms. Initial trials in Haryana have shown promising results, with the robot demonstrating autonomous weeding capabilities.

unnormalised: The KrishiBot prototype uses advanced sensors and AI algorithms to identify and remove weeds without damaging crops. It navigates fields using GPS and visual mapping, covering approximately 1 acre per day. The team claims this is 3x faster than manual weeding, with comparable accuracy. The robot runs on solar power and costs about ₹250,000 to build.
normalised: The KrishiBot prototype uses advanced sensors and A-I algorithms to identify and remove weeds without damaging crops. It navigates fields using G-P-S and visual mapping, covering approximately one acre per day. The team claims this is three times faster than manual weeding, with comparable accuracy. The robot runs on solar power and costs about rupee two hundred and fifty thousand to build.

unnormalised: “We wanted to create a solution that is both affordable and effective for Indian farmers,” explained Dr. Meena Sharma, the project lead. “Many smallholder farms struggle with labor costs and weed infestations. KrishiBot can help reduce these burdens and improve their livelihoods.” The team is now working on incorporating additional functionalities, such as automated irrigation and fertilizer application. They hope to commercialize the technology within the next 2 years.

unnormalised: Funding for the project came from a combination of government grants and private donations. The Ministry of Agriculture has expressed strong interest in supporting the KrishiBot initiative, recognizing its potential to transform the agricultural sector. Further trials are planned in Punjab and Maharashtra to assess its performance in different climatic conditions and with diverse crop types.
